entry.title: The Floating Hourglass
entry.summary: Derek and Zak discuss a strange video of an hourglass trapped in a tube of water. Sometimes the hourglass floats, and other times it stays put.
entry.content:
Introduction

We started by looking at the following animation:

This is very counter intuitive. Though the distribution of mass changes within the hourglass, the total mass and volume is always the same.

In physics we are taught that for Newton's 2nd Law, , we can treat distributed masses like a point, with all of the forces acting at the center of mass. So it seems that the force of gravity and the buoyant force should always be the same. This would imply that the hourglass either always sinks, or always floats since the sum of the external forces is not changing. The odd feeling that this isn't behaving as expected prompted the podcast.

Derek's Hypothesis

Derek came up with a theory about how the hourglass could wedge itself against the walls of the container due to an unstable equilibrium. We know from the start of the GIF that the hourglass wants to float, and therefore it should always float unless another force is acting on it.

Unlike Newton's 2nd Law, when we consider the net torque on a body we can not treat it like a point mass. Thus how the mass is distributed will effect the torque. When the sand is in the upper half, the hourglass would like to flip. But since the walls of the cylinder are preventing it from flipping, it gets stuck. The walls add another force to the system, friction. This frictional force holds the hourglass down prevents it from floating.

As the sand drains to the bottom, the hourglass will right itself vertically, and release itself from the wall. Now the force of friction is gone and the hourglass is free to float again.

As it turn's out, this is the correct answer.

Intuition

When do objects float?

To start we look at any submerged object (not just the cans, but for any object). If gravity and the buoyant forces are the only two forces acting on the object, and it is neutrally buoyant (that is that it neither wants to sink nor float), then we know the following:

Then the buoyant force is defined as the following, where is the density of water (since we are using water) and is the volume of the object. More information and teh derivation of the equation can be seen at Khan Academy's lesson on the buoyant force.

The last equality comes from mass being the product of density and volume. Notice though that since it is the density of water and the volume of the object, we get the mass of the water displaced by the object. This is true of any object submerged in water.

Now we substitute \eqref{eq:Buoy2} into \eqref{eq:Buoy1} to get the condition for neutral buoyancy:

That is to say that the object will be neutrally buoyant when its mass is equal to the mass of the volume of water it has displaced. If then that object will sink. If the object will float. (Often times you see this same condition express in terms of densities.) This is summed up in the following:

It is a scaling that lets us represent the total mass of the system as some amount of cans full of water. i.e. if then the total mass is equal to half of the mass of one of the cans filled with water. Description

Here is our setup. You have two cans submerged in water. The red arrow represents the buoyant force, the purple arrow is the force of gravity.

There are two sliders, one for and the other for . You can slide them to change the amount of sand that is in either can, or the total amount of sand.

Below the sliders is plot of the acceleration of the two cans. In blue you have the acceleration of the right can, and in red the left. Green is the sum of the two accelerations.The yellow line is your current setting for lambda.

Once you've dialed in your values press the play button and watch what happens.

How To Use

You can start by setting the values of and to something you think is interesting. Then use the plot and try to determine what will happen if lambda stays constant. Once you have a guess, press the play button and see what happens.

Try walking through different values of based on what we discussed above. Then for each value of , vary to see what changes. Press the refresh button to but the cans back at their starting positions.

Lastly, you can run the hourglass simulation by clicking on the running man. This will start with all the sand in the right (top) can, and transfer it to the left (bottom) can as time proceeds. This is meant to simulate what happens with the hourglass. Is there ever a situation in which the cans behave like the hourglass did?

Conclusion

From our two can setup we can draw some conclusions. Namely, that Newton was right and objects can be treated like point objects. It should appear obvious that this model does not accurately describe the hourglass and what is going on.

You should have found that only when did the cans move in the same direction at the same time. For all other situations, the right can starts going down and at some point, will begin to go up while the left can will do the opposite.
